Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: NOES
text: New England-Manager of Miles, C. G. Opposition Business) (10.12)-,---1 say to the Leader of the House ( Mr Young) that 1 do not think I have heard more balderdash in my life. One interesting thing came out of this motion and out of what the Leader of the House said about a division on the second reading. I know that there are many factions in the Australian Labor Party, but he has just acknowledged that within the Labor Party there are sufficient for certain members to want to vote against this Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women), because under the Standing Orders the only way in which there can be a division on a measure is if elements within a party are opposed to the measure or there is a majority in the House. I suggest that the Leader of the House has just displayed, once again, that that 28 rump that really is more and more wagging Hawke's tail is in fact the reality in every sphere of this Government's operations. Madam Speaker, I think there is another and far more pertinent aspect to this gag. I think we need to understand that there is a real problem because the Labor Party knows, as we know, that this Bill is not what it pretends to be. It does not provide in any way for better and more equal working opportunities between the sexes; all it is is a compromise as a sop to the radical Left. It is there, not because it is designed to implement equality of opportunity or to provide equality of employment; it is there simply.because the Government felt that it had to go out there and try to persuade a few people that the Bill in some way was going to allay all of those forces that it knows are out there in the community, looking to it to perform. This Bill does not do what it purports to do. Therefore, it should be debated in a full and open way. I find it quite fascinating that the Government had to gag the second reading debate and it is now imposing the guillotine to make sure that worthwhile amendments to the Bill cannot be implemented. I point out that those amendments include, as was mentioned in the second reading contribution by the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong ( Mr Howard), a change to ensure that, if the Bill means anything, it is going to apply to statutory authorities as well as to other fields. Why does the Government not want to do that? If it is genuine about introducing equal employment opportunity, why does it want to deny this House the opportunity of considering worthwhile extensions to ensure that the Bill is more than sound, wind and fury. In reality, in areas in the Australian Public Service,. where this Government discriminates so much against women, and in the trade unions, where we know that the colleagues of the Labor Party discriminate so much against women, measures could be introduced to ensure that there is the same obligation as there is in private sector employment. Needless to say, members of the Opposition totally oppose the denial of members' rights to address this important issue. On that basis, we will oppose the closure of the debate. Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Title: NOES
text: Curtin) (lO.20)-Last night, before the Committee stage of this debate was interrupted, I was making the point in support of the Opposition's amendment to the wording of the short title that the present title was misleadingly descriptive as presented. I quoted the definition of affirmative action in the 1984 Green Paper, and that will appear in yesterday's Hansard. As defined, it has more in common, at least at this initial stage, with the Canadian system than with that of the United States of America. I want to add that the real interest in the American example lies in the way affirmative action has developed in the United States of America. I confess that there may not be an immediate analogy between this proposal and what exists in America today. However anyone familiar with recent American histor; knows that for the best part of a decade and a half the United States Supreme Court backpedalled from the original legislative idea of blind treatment for all regardless of colour and sex. The principle of genuine equality of opportunity for all individuals seems to be viewed as an impediment to the new court agenda in that country, which is raceand sex-conscious decisions for the benefit bf black, female and other minority groups, despite the fact that collectively those groups represent 70 per cent of the United States population and are the holders of three-quarters of the national wealth. The dominant strand in United States legal theory, as enunciated during the past 15 years or so, has studiously avoided or denigrated the concept of raceor sex-neutral treatment of individuals. The new buzz words are 'statistical impact', 'protected groups' and 'discriminatory results', and terms of that order. NOES As I said earlier the relevance of the American example is admittedly not an immediate analogy with this Bill, but it is necessary to remember that it is a simple fact that what the people have in the United States today is not what the Congress very clearly intended. Perhaps in that country they do not have the benefit of the Acts Interpretation Act and its court PAIRS system may not refer to explanatory memoranda and debates in Congress. That is the situation in Andrew. J. N. the United States, and that is one of the concerns that we have with regard to this legislation. It is worth recalling that just a decade or so ago one A: A. Calwell, former parliamentary leader of the Australian Labor Party, wrote this in his book entitled Be Just and Fear Not: In Committee . . . women's lib or those other way out movements that have developed in recent times. Much of the alleged underrepresentation of women ignores the data on years in the work force, relevant qualifications, the views of women a-d the choices many of them make, particularly With regard to home responsibilities. .Again using an example from the United States, because those figures are more readily available, the data shows largely that the real difference is not between men and women but rather, between married women and all othe; persons. For instance, when we look at the United States academic world and women in it, those women who never marry, earn more than academic men who never marry. The system of tenure in academia in Australia might not disclose the same result, but that is a very interesting observation. Secondly, there seems to be also a failure to appreciate the role of the marketplace. Professor Thomas Sowell, the distinguished United States economist and social historian, argues that discrimination is in fact least :-vhere the market is the freest. Again, it seems Important for people to take the time to look in detail at the real world that exists outside sociology seminar rooms. Further, I suggest that all too often the evidence cited in support of claims of discrimination is rather fragile, and it is with those points in mind that I support the Opposition's amendment in relation to the title of this Bill.

Speaker: Mr NEHL
Title: NOES
text: Cowper) (10.27)-I am totally committed to supporting equality of opportunity for all Australians and I am totally opposed to any discrimination in the work place, whether it be on the basis of gender, religion, race or any other factor. I believe it is true that in the past there has been a great deal of discrimination against women and I also believe it is true that even now there are instances where discrimimition does exist. I do not believe that this Bill will do anything at all to assist women to gain equality of opportunity. As I said in an interjection last night, I believe that this Bill is a garbage Bill. the· honourable member for Throsby ( Mr Hollis) took me up on that and complained about my use of the term, but I repeat it, because I do believe that this Bill is a garbage Bill; it is a rubbish Bill; it is a confidence trick, which is just one more in the succession of confidence tricks that are being played by the Hawke Government on the people of Australia. In passing, I congratulate the honourable member for Curtin ( Mr Rocher) who has just spoken, because the point that he made about the major proportion of discrimination in the work force in this country being against married women was a very significant point indeed. I am not opposed to equality of opportunity I believe that it is absolutely vital for the growth of this nation that every Australian has the freedom and ability to use his own potential capacity to create whatever is necessary for the benefit of Australia. In passing, I' would also like to say that I do not and cannot believe that we can have a society where Australians are separated one from the other. I know that, in a caring and compassionate society, which I hope this nation of ours will always be, there are people in need of help· and assistance. Where that help or assistance is needed, it should be dealt with not on the basis of race or gender but, rather, on the basis of need. Similarly, when we are talking about equality of opportunity in employment, the only sensible basis is merit. I cannot support this Bill because it is not really going to do anything which it allegedly sets out to do. I also cannot support it for a number of other reasons: First, it is going to enlarge the bureaucracy and I, as I am sure all of my colleagues in the Opposition, believe that we have reached a stage in Australian society where the bureaucracy does not need to be extended but, rather, reduced. This Bill will elk large the bureaucracy. It will increase government expenditure and, heaven knows, we need to re-.. duce government expenditure. For the past few days we have seen farmers arriving in Canber[from all around New South Wales in order to protest about interest rates, because the costs are killing them. A major reason. for that problem is rampaging government expenditure. This Bill will give trade unions more power. I for one believe that the trade unions in this country do not need any more powers at all."1f anything, we need to control the power of the trade unions in this country. Again, this Bill will impose more regulations on business and, heavens knows, business in this country is in need of deregulation and less. control. This Bill will also impose additional costs on businesses which, in these economic conditions, they cannot possibly undertake .with any degrt,:e of equanimity. We have had changes in Australian society. In August 1966, 30.6 per cent of the labour force was women and in March 1986, 20 years later, that figure had grown to 39.7 per cent. In 20 years we have seen the proportion of women in the labour force increase by approximately one-third. We have had a gradual change in society'S attitude towards equality of opportunity for women in: employment in Australia. Mr Miles-In an orderly way.

Speaker: Mr NEHL
Title: NOES
text: Indeed, in an orderly fashion. What I hope to see is that we continue on this path of orderly change where society itself brings about the change. I do not for one minute believe that the people of Australia are there to serve the Government: The boot is on the other foot. What we must always remember is that the Government is there to serve the people. Society itself is Changing. The figures that I have just quoted demonstrate that quite clearly. What we have to consider is whether, first, a government can legislate to change people's thoughts and attitudes and I do not· really believe that it can .. Even more importantly; unless government is going to get involved in an Orwellian 1984 situation, I do not believe that it is right and proper that a government should pass any legislation that attempts to change the thinking of the people whom the government is there to serve. I think it is a very basic and fundamental point that no government should pass legislation to attempt to brainwash the people whom it is there to serve. I think that the whole issue boils down to a simple choice of evolution or revolution: What the Government purports to be doing with this .Billboil- down to revolution. .As I said, it is a nonsense Bill; it is a garbage Bill and those who pin their faith on it are going. to be. sadly and sorely disappointed once they see what eventuates Jrom it, unless of course the Government is not telling the truth when it says that there will be no quotas. But time will tell. We must consider whether it is better to allow society to change itself, as it is doing, in an evolutionary fashion or whether it is right, correct and proper for the government of the day, of any political complexion, to try to impose change in a revolutionary fashion. I conclude by repeating what I said at the beginning of my remarks: I am totally committed to equality of opportunity for all Australians. I find any suggestion that inequality or discrimination should be encapsulated or incorporated in our society to be anathema. I believe that all Australians must have the opportunity of finding their full potential as citizens. I cannot support the Bill. I would rather see our society change by way of evolution .. I would rather see our society change itself without having change· upon it.

Speaker: Mr CONQUEST
Title: NOES
text: Hinkler) (l0.36)-We are currently discussing a proposed amendment to the title of the Bill which would take but the words 'affirmative action' so that the proposed Act would be entitled the Equal Opportunity in Employment Act. I believe that if We are realistic and if we are to have some legislation in this area, perhaps we should be discussing a proposed Act entitled. the Equal Opportunity for Women Act, and leave out the employment as" pect of it. Had that been the case we may have been able to enshrine some real principles in regard to women by way of this parliamentary procedure. The fundamental issue is not opportunity for women in employment; it should be opportunity for women in Australia. By that means we would have been able to recognise those women in our society who choose to be homemakers, who choose to be mothers-the people of Australia who are being disadvantaged at present and will be further disadvantaged as the implications of this Bill are evidenced in our social thinking.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: NOES
text: I remind the honourable member that we are debating clause I, which is the title of the Bill.

Speaker: Mr CONQUEST
Title: NOES
text: That is quite correct, Mr Chairman. I am pointing out to you that even the change of title will not change the. fundamental principle to which we should be addressing ourselves-that is, equal opportunitY for women in Australia. I do not have to speak In favour of the proposed change. I realise it has been brought forward in faith to take away the affirmative action meaning within theBiIl. But I am saying that we should be discussing equal opportunity for women in Australia. That change would be better than the Bill we have at present and the implications that are inherent in it. This Bill will make the social pressures on the single income family much harder. Even at present we see those who choose to be homemakers-those parents who want to raise a familyare finding that there are pressures as they try to keep up with the affluent two-income family. They cannot really tell Johnnie why he cannot have the things that young Georgie next door has-or should I say also Sally and Jane. Those family units are not compensated by their belief in the sanctity of marriage and the importance of the family unit to Australian society. I know that the Bill mentions forward estimates, but I believe that that is just an appeasement phrase for quotas. It will encourage women into the forced work force and it will also encourage women who are in the work force to stay there, rather than follow their natural inclinations. After all, if they leave the work force it will bring hardship for the family they have, or for other members that they may wish to bring into the family. No amendment can alter the fundamental issue that should be addressed, that is, we should have equal opportunity for women in Australia and we .should take heed that there are women who wish to maintain the sanctity of the family unit. They want to ensure that they are not disadvantaged by any means. Had a more appropriate Bill been before us, we could have addressed those problems to ensure that women were compensated if they wished to follow their natural inclinations in regard to raising a family. We should recognise that, realistically we do have a fundamental problem in that regard. We should recognise that women will not be encouraged to take on the duty of motherhood. I do not see it as a duty, but they do have duties in regard to raising the children and making sure that they mould them into people who will help our society in the future. Our social obligations and our social thinking today were built on the sanctity of marriage and the family unit. I see nothing derogatory in that statement. But some feminist groups are inclined towards ensuring that the family unit is destroyed. This legislation is hastening the evolution which is taking place. We know we must have a change of attitude, but it was shown by the pilot program that this could be achieved by education and less divisive persuasion than that is contained in this Bill. Whilst there are no financial penalties, ther- is a penalty in the threat that persons or corporate bodies may be reported to the Parliament. We have set up a statutory body to ensure that these provisions are carried out. An amount of $I.5m will be spent in its first year of operation. This is another impost on business. Businesses must also put a senior person in charge of the program. So once more business is being asked to pay for the social engineering of this Government. I believe in equal opportunity for women, whether it be in the work place or in the general community. This Government and this Bill do not address those fundamental principles that I have pointed to in regard to those women who want to leave the work place to follow their natural inclinations of motherhood but who worry about the loss of income to the family, and those women who desire to stay at home because they feel that their place in life is to a mother and to raise a family according to Christian principles. Those women in the end will be disadvantaged by this Bill. I believe it a Bill that should never have encompassed employment. Rather it should have enshrined the principles of equal opportunity for women.

Title: NOES
text: Throsby) (10,43)-We are considering clause I of the Bill. Speaker: Mr DRUMMOND
Title: NOES
text: Forrest) (l1.lO)-In addressing myself to clause I, of the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill, which the Opposition has suggested should be called the Equal Opportunities in Employment Bill, I should like to make some broad-ranging remarks, but if honourable members will stick with me they will find that they do relate to this particular clause. This legislation in its present form is quite counterproductive to the interests of all Australians. First, it attempts to legislate for social change when it is quite clear that that social change sought by the legislation is already occurring. Secondly, it is irrational to propose legislation that will not and cannot be enforced by law. Thirdly, the legislation will provide no discernible economic benefit to the community. It will be another sizable cost burden imposed by government on business and will lead to another non-productive bureaucracy in Canberra. Finally, I am particularly concerned that the final outcome of this legislation will be vastly different from the principles of equal opportunity that the Parliament is espousing today. In other words, the consequences of this legislation may not have been thought through. My first point is that the legislation iSlInnecessary. I do not think there is any disagreement in this Parliament that women must have equal opportunity with men in any field. The imbalance of men and women in the work force has existed historically as part of our social structure. As our social structure has evolved this imbalance is being steadily redressed. It is also a function of the work which is now available. Most jobs now do not involve any heavy manual labour so women can compete on equal physical terms with men for the .majority of jobs. There is also anti-discrimination legislation now in place. So where are the barriers? Increases in the female partiCipation rate have occurred across all employment areas in Australia. For males the participation rate declined from 83.5 per cent in 1967 to 75.9 per cent in 1983, while that for females increased from 30.5 per cent in 1967 to 41.8 per cent in 1983. Today women make up some 45 per cent of the work force. There can be no argument that the social change desired by this legislation is occurring very rapidly and without the need for socialist intervention. The bottom line is clearly shown by the latest 1985 Commonwealth Employment Service statistics. There is a ratio of 2: 1 between registered unemployed males and females. It gets worse for the long term unemployed. there were 157,330 registered unemployed males in the 'nine months or over' category while there were only 51,548 females. Unless members of the Government do not believe their own statistics, we are targeting the wrong group in this legislation. Why is it that only half as many women as men seek jobs with the CES? It seems too obvious for words, but in the light of this debate it must be stated. The desire of women to find a paying job is interrupted by marriage, pregnancy and the rearing of children. That is a natural part of life and a desirable social goal for the majority of all Australians. The point is that the Labor social planners cannot expect a 50:50 work force ratio between men and women. We already have an evolving work force where women tend to want part time employment; there is a steady increase in married women entering the work force; younger and older age groups of males are finding decreasing employment prospects; there is a strong tendency to stay unemployed for longer periods and there is a shift away from full employment to part time employment. These are naturally occurring changes, some of which are lamentable. I can assure the Government that for the majority of Australians equal opportunity exists and is reflected by the statistics. That is apart from a small but significant vocal minority. Women are not represented equally at the administrative, executive and managerial levels with men. As of May 1984 there were some 375,800 males employed in this type of work as against 62,800 females. It is for this group of wOmen that affirmative action is intended to apply. I was interested to read what Professor Hartmen of the University of Missouri said on the United States experience with affirmative action. She believes that affirmative action in the United States has helped privileged women and that the majority of other women have been left behind; that is the United States affirmative action program has only accelerated the trend in the top echelon. It has been unable to effect changes in the traditional labour markets beyond those that would nurmally have occurred. My second point is that I simply cannot see the need to legislate in areas where such legislation cannot or will not be enforced. Why have a law if it cannot be enforced? That is a basic question and one with which the Government should come to grips. The alternative to this legislation should be a campaign based on a uniform code on equal opportunity. To explain this point more clearly I should point out that this legislation over a four-year period will quire all businesses employing more than 100 people to submit two reports annually to the Director of Affirmative Action showing how they are implementing this policy. This will involve about 50 per cent of the work force. The other section of the work force, those working in organisations employing fewer than 100 peoplesome 3.3 miIlion workers-will miss out on the benefits of all this report writing. How will affirmative action be advanced in these sections of the work force? Any reasonable person would see that a publicity campaign would be far more effective in achieving results. The third point I mention is the economic implications of the affirmative action program. The existing pilot program has already been run in 30 companies and three educational establishments. According to the Business Council of Australia, it has cost one company $750,000 to participate. Businesses will be required to allocate staff and resources to the program, particularly in the initial phase, to keep up the paper work. The Government will establish yet another department, which will probably cost $1.5m to run in 1986-87. This will certainly escalate as the work load increases sevenfold by 1990. WiII this contribute one bit to Australia's efficiency? Is business so slow that it does not select the right person for the job now? The strong inference is that business cannot see the wood for the trees, but the Government can. Many people may argue that affirmative action is a voluntary code, so we should not be all that alarmed. As the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) mentioned in his second reading speech, the Director could use this provision to prepare special reports on the employment of women in particular industries or occupations or to provide information on successful approaches and methods for effective affirmative action programs. On translation of the Hawke speak, it is a voluntary program as long as it achieves .its objectives. I do not think anyone could be assured for a minute that if this legislation were passed it would not be amended substantially in the short term. Clearly it will not achieve its goals, go by the United States, Canadian or British experience. One of the main aspects I find distressing is that the Government has not considered the consequences.· This is not surprising. We have had many disasters since the Labor Party came to office, where things have not been properly thought through. Some examples are the steady re- rise in the cost of rental accommodation after the disallowance of negative gearing; the imposition of the capital gains tax for investors; and the loss to investors in rural areas of Australia because the Labor Government has disallowed offsetting losses on primary production against other earned income-just to mention a few. I hope that someone in Government has sat down and thought through the possible long term effects of this legislation. Is it essential that the Government speed up the natural evolution process in this instance? This is further legislation that will lead to the fragmentation of society. By picking out sections of society for special treatment we will end up with reverse discrimination against the members of majority groups in society. As I have said previously, we may be led to believe that this legislation will help all women and is broadly based across society, but that is not true. It will probably advantage only a small elite section of the work force, if the experience of the United States and other countries can be used as a guide.

text: Macarthur) (11.20)-We are debating the first clause, which is the title, of the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill. As I said last night, I believe it is appropriate that the title remain, because the legislation is drafted to ensure that all large employers take seriously their obligations to their women employees. I will use two examples to show how true that assertion is. I feel sure that many honourable members on the other side, particularly those in the National Party· of Australia, would echo the sentiments that have been expressed on the question of equal employment opportunity by Jim Kirk, the Chairman and Managing Director of Esso Australia Ltd. In an address he gave to the Institute of Directors in Australia in July 1985, he said: There is no doubt that EEO is a management issue for the 1980s and 1990s. I urge you to fight the introduction of EEO by legislation or government decree as I believe that to be counter-productive. Keep to yourself the right to act as you see fit-but you must act and be seen to if we act if you want to avoid force. That was said by a man who is in control of one of the largest companies in Australia. It is an interesting point of view-some would say it is a contradiction in terms-particularly given Esso's successful and voluntary affirmative action pilot program. I believe that the efforts of that company serve to illustrate how important are the principles of affirmative action; yet comments by someone such as the Managing Director give credence to those of us on this side who maintain that there is a need to ensure that those principles are put in place through legislation. I give a further illustration of the Esso case. In just five years to 1984 the number of women in the management professional area of Esso's work force has increased from 3 per cent to 11 per cent; up from 22 to 117 women professionals. These women include 11 engineers, 17 geos· cientists, 31 accountants and 20 computer specialists. Those are fields, which traditionally over the years have never gone to women, where women are now receiving equal employment opportunity through affirmative action programs; albeit a voluntary one with this company, which is now being criticised by the Managing Director. Similarly, in the clerical and technical areas the number of women has increased from 39 per cent to 55 per cent; up from 181 to 291 women. This recruitment includes technicians, apprentices and trainee gas plant operators in nontraditional work areas. That is most important, because the success in getting women into those non-traditional areas, about which my colleague the honourable member for Lowe ( Mr Maher) spoke previously, is a significant achievement. It is through this basic tenet of the affirmative action legislation that the opportunity is there to regard people as equal. As I said in this debate last night, what we are talking about is not some way of saying that women should be regarded as more equal than men and there should be some positive bias in favour of them; we are suggesting that they should compete with men on an equal footing for available positions. If two people go for a job and their qualifications are taken into consideration, there should be no bias in favour of a man over a woman. I compare what has happened in the Esso situation with something that has happened in the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. .I refer particularly to the Australian hon and Steel Pty Ltd case in Wollongong. Women have been locked out of many sections of the workplace for a number of years and there has been an abject failure of other organisations to implement the affirmative action principles. Accordingly, those organisations need a gentle push in the right direction. As I have said, BHP is a case in point. Many of my constituents, as honourable members would know-certainly the honourable member for Throsby ( Mr Hollis) who shares that great area of the Illawarra with the honourable member for Cunningham ( Mr West) and me-are affected by some of the decisions that have been taken by BHP in respect of women in the work force. A very long running saga has developed in New South Wales Equal Opportunity Tribunal, where three types of complaints were lodged by a number of women; significantly, a large number of ethnic women. The honourable member for Lowe touched on this problem of women with English language difficulties, who are discriminated against because of difficulties of background and so on. The Tribunal heard three types of complaints from a number of women who sought recompense from AIS at Port Kembla. There was discrimination on the ground of failure to hire; discrimination in the threat of retrenchment; and discrimination in actual retrenchment. In that case last year employment practices were shown to discriminate quite clearly against women in the selection of employees for manual work. Yet, once hired, the practice of last-on, first-off effectively prevented any change in the workplace. Therefore, the opportunities for women in non-traditional areas were hindered. The Tribunal concluded that the first-on, last-off policy was unreasonable. The Tribunal stated: We think it was unreasonable and unfair to apply a gate seniority test to victims of past discrimination without making an appropriate adjustment in order to avoid exacerbating the adverse effects of that discrimination. That quite clearly demonstrates some of the problems faced by women in non-traditional areas. The results of that decision have been somewhat heartening. To their great credit, AIS-BHP-has had some positive input into the employment processes associated with its plant at Port Kembla. Women on the waiting list for employment have been contacted by AIS and some have already been employed. That speaks volumes for that organisation, although I note that it lodged an appeal in the courts against that decision. When we are talking about the problems in the work force and the problems with affirmative action, what we should be concerned about is the ability for women to compete effectively on an equal footing \\ Ilh men for a variety of tasks. Certainly we have seen that opportunity in professional ranks over some time now, but as I mentioned last night, in the non-technical side of things, the non-traditional areas of employment, women have been discriminated against positively for a long time. It is interesting how that has led in this day and age to the use of specific terms to describe how women's men's roles in society have evolved. If we look at some of the more outrageous statements that have been made over time, such as those clearly demonstrated in Gloria Steiwomenem's book Outrageous Acts and Everyday Reas bellions, we can clearly get a feeling of how this problem has developed. For example, of work has been a major area of understanding, beginning with that word itself. Before vent of feminism and people becoming interested in affirmative action and equal employment opyoung portunity, work was largely defined as what men did or would do; thus a working women was defined as someone who laboured outside the home for money masculine style. Certainly that would be one of the greatest putdowns I have ever heard. The equal pay for equal work confor cept came into play in the 1960s but fell short of helping women in the female, non-unionised jobs, and helped to create the term 'pink collar ghetto'. Another quote is worth looking at too. 1972 a National Aeronautics and Space Adminwith istration official's view of women's functions space-yes, NASA started to train women for space-was that they were nothing more than 'sexual diversion on long duration flights such to Mars'. Now, of course, NASA simply calls them astronauts, just like the men. This sort language clearly demonstrates the way we have gone and why it is necessary that such positive legislation as this be introduced.

Their ideas do of come through in legislation. Let us have a look at some of the ideas of Dr Anne Summers. The following was said by Dr Summers less than a year ago: Targets were an integral part of affirmative action. This legislation is really nonsense. It is a sham; it is .trite. In moving this amendment we are to clarify what this Bill really is all about, which is giving equal opportunity. It is not afaction in anybody's definition of the in word. When we have a look at what is said in terms of affirmative action we find statements as 'to make Forward Estimates'. We say 'I wonder what a forward estimate is' and the reply is 'a quantitative· measure in numerical That is setting a target if an employer takes it Up and sets a particular target for men women in the work force. It therefore does become a target but, of course, it is a selftarget. I suggest to employers that what they should do with this legislation is not to change the ratio of men to women in their work force one iota. I will be telling the large employers in my area exactly that because if they change the ratio they will be acknowledging that they were discriminating in the past, but it is likely that they were not; they probably were giving jobs on merit. If they change the ratio they will be virtually bound by the legislation of this Federal Government, which likes to pass legislation to change the social engineering of this country. I believe that social changes in Australia should come about not by legislation, but .by natural changes. I will illustrate what has been going on by giving figures for the work force over the last 15 years. In 1970 males occupied 73 per cent of the work force; women, 26 per cent. Over the next 15 years the proportion of men in the work force dropped to 61 per cent, and the proportion of women increased to 38 per cent. If that natural progress were to continue without government legislation, without any more bureaucracy in this nation-which many of us know we can ill afford because of our high debt, and because it is an added impost on the Australian taxpayers which is totally unnecessary-by the year 2000 there would be more women than men in the work force. Therefore, there is no need for the involvement of government in this area. The social changes and values which are occurring in our society are occurring naturally and are orderly. There is another aspect to what is happening in our society and 1 refer to this in the last few minutes allowed to me. As women return to the work force we find that there is a greater number of families without an income. There are 150,000 families in Australia without one income; yet 54 per cent of Australian families have two incomes. At the same time as social changes occur-and I believe in equal opportunity for women and in women coming back into the work force-many working class families are losing out. There are many working class families in my area who are losing out because the families in which both the wife and the husband are well educated can compete more effectively in the job market. The consequence is that there are families which are becoming very wealthy at the expense of the working class families of Australia. 1 think that there is a greater priority for Australia than equal opportunity. 1 agree with it, but as far as priorities for governing nation go, we should give priority to ensuring that every family has an income; then maybe some families could compete to have two incomes. 1 think that is a greater priority socially for this nation than is the priority of equal opportunity. I believe that within a family we can give equal opportunity to either the male or the female to be the breadwinner-I do not mind which. 1 think the priority of every family having an income is very important. Finally, this legislation is really based on changes in our society that have occurred in the last 10 or 15 years. One of those changes has been to move towards a materialistic society where the person who earns the income has the status. That person who earns a large income, who can buy better cars, a bigger house and so on is the person who is valued. 1 reject that notion very strongly. What we should do is put an equal value on those people who are involved in the nurturing and the personal development of human beings rather than trying to change all our population into people who seek material wealth.· To achieve these goals, we should be putting value on the people who are caring for children and giving them a reasonable status in society so that they feel fulfilled. 1 do not mind whether that caring is done by me or by my wife; we are very happy to share that sort of arrangement. The problem is that some'people, particularly the radical feminists, believe the only way in which women can get a foot in in this society is by going out and competing in male-dominated areas. That is total nonsense. They have sold the idea that there is a power struggle between men and women in society. There is not. Men and women are complementary, and they find enjoyment in life and use their resources best by working together. 1 believe that we ought to change this title to the Equal Opportunity in Employment Bill.

text: Curtin) (11.47)-As a matter of principle, I resent government prescribing management and personal policies of business and I must therefore be critical of legislation requiring a prescribed affirmative action program. In saying that, I am mindful of the additional costs this legislation will inflict on an already overregulated and overburdened business community. I am concerned about the practical difficulties businesses face in implementing unihave form legislation of this kind. ' Pages 6, 11, 12, 24, 25 and 26 of the report of the Government's own working party on affirmative action legislation record the concerns of the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Business Council of Australia, members who participated in the pilot program, the Victorian Employers Federation, the Chamber of Mines of to Western Australia, the Chamber of Manufacthere tures of New South Wales, the Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia, the Institute of Personnel Management Australia, Esso Ausof tralia Ltd, Lend Lease Corporation Ltd, and the but West pac Banking Corporation. Page 12 of the of all those women report notes: All of these submissions opposed legislation requiring of a prescribed affi rmat ive action program . . . is The honourable member for Macarthur ( Mr Martin) quoted Mr Jim Kirk of Esso. I refer him to that pUblication to get a different aspect. Pages 24 and 25 of the report cite the Business Council of Australia as strongly opposing 'the that legislation is either appropriate or necessary to achieve the Government's objectives of employment opportunity for women. The BCA went on to note: This view is shared by the whole of the business (and, indeed, many in Government) and the believes there would not be widespread community support for the creation of a new agency. A mandatory Government program with an expensive bureaucratic structure would be seen as a further on Government expenditure, a departure from the of State and Federal Governments for less rather than more intrusive and costly regulation . . . On page 25 of the report we are told that the Confederation of Australian Industry argued: Affirmative action legislation is unnecessary, undesirwill add to employers' costs and will have counterof the radical productive effects. Those are scarcely ringing endorsements. My inprinciple doubt about this Bill was only strengthened when I examined chapter 3 of the working report dealing with the. Government's pilot program that commenced on 2 July 1984 and ran for some 12 months. There were eight key steps in the Government's implementation strategy as set out for the pilot program. Of those steps, half-that is four-were not undertaken by all participants. One may ask: Which four? Step three was the process of so-called consultation with trade unions. Step four involved consultation with employees. Step seven was similarly ignored, probably because it required the setting of goals and targets to endea. vour to improve the representation of women in all areas of the organisation. 'Step eight was also ignored: . . . the process of establishing monitoring and evaluation to assess whether the goals and targets achieved and, if not, the reasons for this occurring. Again, that is scarcely an inspiring result, particularly as those steps not undertaken by all participants are the most difficult to implement and will prove most controversial in the work place. Anyone who doubts my view should consult page 12 of the report for the opinion of the Shop Distributive and Allied Employees Association, which 'opposed the inclusion of the setting of goals and targets as a requirement of programs.' I must also record my concern at the proposals that came from the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the National Women's Consultative Council. The NWCC wanted all employers to be covered, including voluntary organisations, and called for the provisions of the Bill to apply to all employees, including casual and contract workers, to provide sanctions, and to speed up the timetable for private sector compliance. The ACTU wanted much stronger impositions, including coverage of all employers, a range of sanctions and penalties, the existing legislative proposal for union consultations to be strengthened, and the timetable for compliance to be shortened. Given the overwhelming influence of the ACTU on the Government it is quite likely that in the not too distant future we will see amendments to this legislation to expand its scope and the strength of its already intrusive powers. I believe that the legislators must pay attention to the unanticipated as well as the intended consequences of their actions. It has been suggested, most recently by the Chairman of the Public Service Board, Dr Peter Wilenski, that concern about the American experience with affirmative action is rather fanciful in the Australian context. I draw the attention of the Committee, firstly, to Article I (4) and Article 2 (2) of the International Convention on the Elimi. nation of All Forms of Racial Discrimination, and to Article 4 of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. The respective articles allow for affirmative action on the American model, that is; so called positive discrimination or reverse discrimination, giving preferential or compensatory treatment to members of racial, sex, ethnic or other groups. That may include quotas involving preferential treatment in hiring, promotion, or in admission to an educational institution. Australia has ratified both those conventions. Further, I remind the Committee of the willingness of the High Court in recent times to were make what might be politely described as surprisingly innovative interpretations of the law and the Constitution. The Koowarta and the Tasmanian dam cases stand as testimony to Professor A. R. Blackshield's observation that the Court is deliberately modifying its interpretations of the Constitution 'so as to bring them more closely into line with the country's political ne¢ds'. Leaving aside for the moment a debate about just what are the country's political needs, Professor Blackshield's observations serve as a timely reminder of the long term dangers Australia faces now that the High Court has abandoned the doctrine of strict constructionalism associated with such distinguished jurists. as Sir Owen Dixon and Sir John Latham in the dubious search for contemporary political relevance.' While not making any immediate prophecies, it. might be useful to recall once again the warning issued by Sir Robert Menzies in 1974 that there might one day be a High Court that says: 'The sky is the limit'. This concerrt is given added impetus when we consider the potential, if I might so describe it, of Australia's Bill of Rights. Returning to the immediate effect of this Bill, we are left with Dr Wilenski's assurance that quotas, that is, mandatory selection of a certain number of people from a particular group regardless of merit, can be effectively differentiated from targets. He referred to an estimate of the number that might be selected if so-called barriers are removed and positive steps such as recruitment and training programs are undertaken. As I mentioned earlier, the Canadian Government has a similar scheme to this proposal in operation in its Public Service. Like this Government, Canada maintains that its approach is reasonable, flexible and compatible with appointment according to merit. It maintains that there is a sharp difference between its approach and the American approach. That is not borne out by information included in the 1983 annual report of the Australian Public Service Board. Because my time is about to expire, I would like to refer honourable members to the words of the Public Service Commissioner, Jennifer MCQueen.

text: Before calling the Chairman of Committees, I draw the attention of the House to the constitutional question this message involves. The message purports to repeat the requests for amendments contained in message No. 166 which the House rejected at its sitting of 28 November 1985. The 'right' of the Senate to repeat and thereby press of insist on a request for an amendment has never been accepted by the House of Representatives. On several previous occasions when a request was pressed on the House by repetition the House had regard to the claim that the public welfare required passage of the legislation .which was the subject of the pressed request and gave the pressed request the House's consideration notwithstanding that the House resolved to refrain from determining its constitutional rights. The House so informed the Senate of the terms of its, resolution in its message to the Senate in reply. It is not certain whether the Senate's 'right' to Act" (both inclusive). substipress a request by repetition is justiciable in the courts. However, it is a matter of constitutional propriety as between the Houses based on the provisions of sections 53 to 57 of the Constitution. Strong arguments that the Constitution does not give the Senate the right to press a request were advanced by Quick and Garran, who were intimately involved in the development of the Constitution. Their views may be found on pages 671-2 of their treatise on the Constitution. In 1943, some 40 years later, the question was examined by four eminent constitutional lawyers-Garran, Knowles, Bailey and Castieauwho, after considering other learned opinion, summed up the question in the following words: In our opinion, the Constitution in denying the right of amendment and conferring the right of request intended a substantial difference. In this we respectfully agree with the views expressed by Sir Harrison Moore, Sir Isaac Isaacs, and Sir John Latham. We think it clear that the Constitution did not intend to stultify itself by giving back in one clause what it had taken away in another. The essence of the difference between request and amendment is that in the case of a request the right of decision as to the form of the Bill rests solely with the House of Representatives. To press a request is to insist upon it-which is a contradiction in terms, and also in our opinion unconstitutional . . . Other more recent legal opinion has been of similar view, including the opinions of Professors Richardson, Sawyer and Pearce. I respectfully agree with these opinions, as did Speaker Snedden on 21 October 1981 and Speaker JenMadam kins as recently as 20 August 1985. It rests the House whether it will consider message No. 175 insofar as it purports to press the requests that were contained in message No. 166. Motion (by Mr Holding) proposed: That this House(I) endorses the statement of the Speaker in relation to the constitutional questions raised by Message No. 175 tran-mitted from the Senate in relation to the Veterans' Entitlements Bill 1985; . text: Melbourne Ports-Minister for Aboriginal Affairs) (12.25)-For the information of honourable members and those participating in the debate, I table the explanatory notes to the Veterans' Entitlements Bill. The Veterans' Entitlements Bill 1985 was passed by this House on 12 November 1985. The Bill is the culmination of an extensive revie- of existing repatriation legislation and a long proc.ess of consultation with the ex-service community. Its purpose is to consolidate, rationalise and simplify the entitlements available to members of the veteran community. The Bill contains some significant extensions of benefits. However, the Bill failed to pass the Senate. That chamber made a number of wide-ranging amendments to the Bill and requested the House· to make other amendments. While the Government does not accept all the requests and amendments made by the Senate, it does, in a spirit of co-operation and compromise; propose to make a number of amendments to the Bill. The Government pro- . poses to deal in its amendments with all but two of the 41 amendments or requests made by the Senate. One, involving unpaid pension at the time of the death of a pensioner, will be resolved by administrative means. The.other is an amendment to the standard of proof provisions of clause 119 in relation to claims for pension lodged prior to IS May 1985. This amendment was moved because of the Opposition's phoney claim that the clause is retrospective. The Government does not accept that the clause is retrospective, nor does the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I ask honourable members to note the' report of that Committee. . In Committee The amendment would require all claims lodged before IS May 1985 to be examined on the standard of proof applicable at the time, that is, without a requirement for a reasonable hypothesis of a connection with war service. It Schedule A would also require all claims lodged before IS May 1985 and decided since 6 June 1985 to be "alreconsidered. The amendment is therefore clearly unrealistic. It would mean that virtually all claims lodged before IS May 1985 would have to be "defaccepted. The cost of this has been estimated at and 36, $25m in the first year and up to $80m over three years. In addition, the Government would be compelled to find this extra $80m to pay pensions to those who have no moral claim to them, to those who are not able to establish the nexus between the injury or the illness from which they are suffering and their war .service. Yet in a situation where even when there was no reasonable suggestion of a link between the veterleave an's incapacity or death and his or her servicewhere there was not even a scintillapf evidence suggesting a war service relationship-such a veteran would be able to make claims. The effect of this would be to shorten very considerably the amount of funds available to the Minister and the Department to meet the more legitimate and more extensive claims by those servicemen whose entitlements rest clearly on an established war service relationship. How often do we hear members of the Opposition saying to the public that there is a need to cut back on public expenditure, that there is a need to restrain costs? I think .that many of those arguments are legitimate.

Title: NOES
text: I shall move that motion now, Mr Chairman. The requested amendments pressed by the Senate are not acceptable to the Government in the form that they are before us. They would be acceptable to the Government in another form and a schedule indicating those amendments and requested amendments acceptable to the Government has been circulated to honourable. members. It is not competent for this Committee under the Standing Orders to agree to the amendments in the form which is acceptable to the Government at this stage because this Committee is empowered only to modify Senate requests for amendments and not to agree to amendments in their place. Therefore, I propose to move: 'That the amendments requested by the Senate be not made'. Provided the report of this Committee is adopted by the House, I will move in the following terms: That, in the message returning the Bill to the Senate, the Senate be informed that its requests for amendments would be acceptable to the House in the form indicated in Schedule C if proposed in conjunction with certain amendments also indicated in Schedule C. Therefore, at this stage I move: That the amendments requested by the Senate be not made. Continuing with the line of reasoning I was putting to the chamber, the effect of the amendment would be that unwarranted pensions would be paid at the expense of the benefits, services and treatment entitlements of those who have already established their right to them. It could also mean that 27,000 claims decided since 6 June would go to the front of the determining queue ahead of everyone else for reconsideration, regardless of the outcome of the original decision. This would mean massive delays-delays of 12 months-causing severe hardship and distress to less favoured members of the veteran community, many of them widows who are awaiting a decision on their more recent claims. As I said earlier, the Government does not accept that clause 119 of the Bill is retrospective. The issue is phoney. The Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee does not. accept that the clause is retrospective. The Chairman of that Committee, Senator Tate; in a letter of 12 March 1986 to the Minister for· Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) restated the view of the Committee, expressed in· its sixteenth report of 1985, and I table the letter. Senator Tate said: While it is clear that this provision will put applicants in a new and less advantageous position, the Committee indicates as a matter of record that it accepts the Government's view that the application of the altered standard of proof in the determination of claims and appeals after the date on which the amending legislation came into operation does not involve any retrospectivity (even though such claims and appeals may have been lodged or initiated prior to the commencement of the amending legislation). Senator Tate continued, and I ask the House to note his words: The Committee uses retrospectivity in its dictionary meaning of statutes having a retroactive operation, for example licensing or punishing past action. As Professor D. C. Pearce, a former Legal Adviser to the Committee states in his standard work, Statutory Interpretatio(2nd ed. Butterworths, Sydney, 1981), at page 149: Few Acts do not interfere with some existing right. The usual intention of a legislation is to make some change in an existing course of conduct. It is, therefore, appropriate to talk in terms of retrospectivity only where an Act affects rights by changing them with effect prior to the commencement of the amending Act. In short, to be termed retrospective, legislation must affect existing rights or benefits. By contrast, this legislation has an explicit savings clause-clause 6 of the associated transitional Bill-which guarantees the continuity of pensions at existing levels. It means that no existing beneficiary will suffer a loss or reduction of pension. The ex-service community also has not supported the amendment. A meeting of all ex-service organisations on 13 February 1986 opposed the amendment and called for the immediate passage of the Veterans' Entitlement Bill. Indeed, in an advertisement in the 19 March issue of the House Magazine the National Secretary of the Returned Services League, Mr Ian Gollings, said: T.he RSL with 269,767 members, Legacy with over 7,000, the War Widows' Guild with 25,000 and the TPI Federation representing 20,675 veterans are strongly united in calling on the Opposition to not press its remaining amendment. While it is calling for the Government to cut ,spending the Opposition is persisting with an amendment which would increase spending in an area where there is no demand from the ex-service community. The concern is that the action taken by the Opposition could jeopardise funding for repatriation hospitals and other urgent improvements in the Veterans' Affairs portfolio. The Government's amendments have been circulated to the Opposition and the Australian Democrats and I understand that, with the possible exception of the amendment to clause 119, they are acceptable to them. The ex-service community has also been fully consulted on the Government's proposals. For those reasons, I commend to the House the course of action that is now being proposed by the Government.

Title: NOES
text: Farrer) (12.36)-The Government has only itself to blame for the delays that have occurred to the Veterans' Entitlements Bill and related legislation. The commitment of the coalition parties has been to fight unnecessary and unfair cutbacks on veterans and to fight for veterans who submitted claims and applications before May 1985. I wish to draw the attention of the House to page 4044 of Hansard of 29 November 1985 in proof of my comments. Here we are many months later about to resume consideration of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill, yet these requests were first brought back to the House of Representatives on 29 November 1985 at 4.29 p.m. The Government adjourned the House and failed to take any measure to bring on the discussions on that particular occasion. It has been the Government's determination as to when this should be brought forward for further consideration because it controls the numbers in the House of Representatives. I want to spell out the coalition's attitude strongly. We cannot be blamed for the delay because we have been absolutely responsible throughout all the deliberations on the Veterans' Entitlements Bill. We have eventually reached the stage where, after a lot of consultations with the Returned Services League and other veteran's organisations, we have taken a very strong stand on a raft of amendments, some of which the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs ( Mr Holding) has already referred to. The result of all these has been the removal of that discriminatory 40-year rule which no government of this country worth a pinch of salt should ever have dreamt up in the first place. Let me just remind the House and the nation that veterans and war widows especially were to have been subjected to a very unfair discriminatory proposal by the Government but for the stand of the coalition. Our stand has been to fight the cutbacks which have emerged along the track, some of which have been obliquely referred to in this Bill. I refer to the totally and permanently incapacitated pension criteria tightening up, on which evidence was given in the Senate Estimates Committee yesterday. That has resulted in a reduction of between $20m and $24m in outlays for the Government on the granting of TPI. According to RSL figures, the cutbacks in travel allowances have already resulted in a reduction of $3m expenditure for the Government and the cutbacks in the dental scheme with unfair limitations on four categories of treatment which, in the words of a Launceston dentist are leading to veterans missing out on essential dental treatment, have led to reductions in expenditure of $5.6m since that infamous mini-Budget in which the veterans took more than their fair share of the cutbacks imposed by the Government at that time. Above all, we have the cutbacks of the assets test as it is applied to service pensioners. I will not dwell on that although it is not outside the scope of this Bill because the Bill revalidates the assets test for service pensioners. Already more than 13,000 veterans have had their pensions reduced or cancelled as a consequence of the application of the assets test. That burden has fallen very heavily on veterans, more so than on general pensioners. That is why the coalition has taken a strong and consistent stand on this legislation throughout its passage through the Parliament and that is why we will continue to do so. Our stand in no way affects the fundamental future operation of this legislation. In fact, both Houses and all parties have agreed to its future operation. Our stand now relates particularly to the matter of retrospectivity. I have much pleasvery ure in reminding the House of some of the more relevant quotes that have come in from time to time on the issue of retrospectivity-an issue pursued by all veterans' organisations throughout 1985. I have a great deal of respect for those organisations. They were subjected to additional pressures to formulate a slightly different viewpoint in more recent weeks. Let me remind the House what the Partially Blinded Soldiers Association of Australia said on 2 February 1986 about retrospectivity. It said: The retrospectivity clause is outrageous. It appears as a deliberate attempt by the Minister or the Treasurer, or both, to avoid paying the disabled veteran money to which he is rightFully entitled. The Government is quibbling about a national debt owed to its disabled fighting men, those who preserved For us the benefits and way of liFe we enjoy in Australia today. I could say that at this stage my case rests, but I will continue and h;ghlight the comments of the Regular Defence Forces Welfare Association which likened the retrospectivity matter to 'removing the goal post during a football match'. Those are fairly strong words and they reflect the concern that exists over the retrospectivity issue. While there is legal debate about the extent to which the legislation is retrospective, I am reminded of a letter from the late Senator Alan Missen on this matter. I went to see Senator Missen and asked him about this. He wrote in these terms: J believe the Committee report unfortunately does not fully cover the decision of the Committee and lacks clarity. At least a word should be inserted to show that the provision' does not come within the definition of retrospectivity in a formal senseas he explained to me by that he meant in a technical senseundoubtedly it does lead to the imposition of real financial burden on applicants who commenced their proceedings while a certain state of law existed and then found themselves financially prejudiced by a later amendment of the law. The Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee itself went on to say, as the Minister mentioned a moment ago, that it was clear that this provision would put applicants in a new and less advantageous position. Our amendment goes to the nub of the question and provides two objectives: That the applications submitted before May that have not yet been determined should be determined on the basis of the law as it then stood; and that with those applications which had been determined, the veteran should have the right to make a claim for a review which would then also be on the basis of the law as it then stood. I have made a copy of that amendment available to the Government. I hope that the amendment will be properly dealt with in the Senate because Standing Orders and other factors preclude its being moved here. Our approach in both Houses has been consistent in respect of this Veterans' Entitlements Bill and I wish to emphasise that my stand has been predicated on the basis of wide-ranging co-operation, and that those out in the veterans' community at large, across Australia, are sick to death of the cutbacks, confusion and complex changes that this Government has brought to the portfolio of Veterans' Affairs. They want to see a determined stand made in their interests to ensure that the full and just entitlements are accorded to those who served their country in time of war. I wish to emphasise that there is a need, because of the complexity of this legislation, for a monitoring committee to be established. That committee should be independent and have particular reference to the TPI changes which are causing very real concern in many veterans' organisations. The committee should also ensure that the legislation is not having effects that were not intended and that proper recommendations are made after clause 119 standard of proof has been in operation for a long period. It is essential that such a monitoring committee be established.
