Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Bennelong-Leader of the Opposition) (2.22)-I move: This House censures the Prime Minister for I. His weak and abject failure to dismiss the Minister for Trade; 2. Condoning the failure of the Minister for Trade to make full and frank disclosure of matters which may have given rise to a conflict of interest; 3. Allowing the Minister for Trade to remain within the Ministry despite his proven record of poor judgment and a failure to understand the propriety demanded of a Minister; 4. Breaking his promise that Ministers in his Government would disclose any matters which may involve a conflict of interest; 5. His failure to maintain proper standards of ministerial conduct; 6. His blatant double standards relating to ministerial propriety; 7. His expedient and opportunistic interpretation of rules he himself has laid down for the conduct of Ministers; and 8. His continued choice of cronyism and factional survival in preference to his duty as Prime Minister to maintain both real and apparent standards of integrity. I commence my remarks on this censure motion by saying that there is only one issue involved in the affairs of the past 48 hours and thqt is the propriety of the behaviour of the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke). I remind the House of a number of things that have been said on the subject of ministerial propriety and ministerial behaviour. I start first of all with a comment made on 27 April 1982 by none other than the Leader of the House and Special Minister of State ( Mr Young). The Leader of the House would be the world's greatest expert on ministerial propriety, would he not? The Leader of the House would know more about ministerial propriety than just about any other member of the Hawke Government, because he has been more guilty of breaching the standards of ministerial propriety than any other member of that Government. Let me remind honourable members of what the Leader of the House-the honourable member for Port Adelaidehad to say on 27 April 1982: Nothing is more important than the way in which these people who are called Ministers behave themselves and set an example to other people in Australia. Nothing is more important than the relationship between the Government and the people of Australia. Those were the words of the Leader of the House and Special Minister of State in 1982. I now go on to a comment made by none other than the Prime Minister on 16 November 1977: If a man . . . shouts from the roof tops that those in high office should be subject to scrutiny he should have exactly those same standards applied to himself. How relevant are those words. How prophetic it was of the Prime Minister to say in 1977 that if a person shouts from the rooftops about propriety in high places he should watch out that those words do not come back to bite him. That prophecy made by the Prime Minister applies with deadly accuracy to his colleague the Minister for Trade ( Mr Dawkins). Nobody in my memory, in 11 years in the Parliament, more used and abused the forms of this House to shout from the rooftops about ministerial propriety than did the Minister 'for Trade. Those who sat on the Government side before 1983 will remember that day after day he traduced reputations; he insulted family members; he used the sanctity of the privilege of this House to traduce the reputations of innocent Australians outside this Parliament. If ever a man made for himself a future burden because of the standards he then demanded of others, if ever a person impugned the reputation and the decency and integrity of honest members of the former Government, it is the present Minister for Trade. It is therefore not surprising that in 1982, in a moment of total reflection, he also had something prophetic to say. This is what he had to say: Getting stuck into them-that is the Liberalsmeans you've got to be pretty careful about your own conduct because, if you're even slightly flawed it's to become a matter of much greater interest to them than if you are sitting there back in Parliament and saying nothing. They were the words of the present Minister for Trade back in 1982. I can teU him and the Prime Minister that the issue is of enormous importance to us because what has occurred on this occasion is a total breakdown in the standards of disclosure required of a senior Minister of the Crown. All the bobbing and weaving and squirming of the Prime Minister, his redefinition of rules that he laid down in 1983, his contradiction today of what he said yesterday, his colleague's contradiction yesterday of what he had said earlier in that same day, the fact that the Government has now adopted such an absurd position on this issue that it no longer has a tenable position on the disclosure of material interests, demonstrate the trap into which the rantings and ravings of the Minister for Trade when he was in opposition have led him. There is only one issue involved, and it has nothing to do with whether this Government or any other government maintains a public register of the pecuniary interests of Ministers or members of their immediate families. It has nothing to do with that. That is a total and comprehensible red herring. There is only one thing involved and that is whether or not, in the circumstances applying to the Minister for Trade, there was a potential for a conflict of interest to arise. The Prime Minister cannot hide behind the narrow definition of the immediate family. He cannot hide behind that kind of legalistic approach. The simple fact, as the Prime Minister ought to know and ought to have admitted yesterday, and as the Minister for Trade ought to have known when he went to the meeting of the Cabinet sub-committee, is that conflicts of interest can arise involving the activities and assets of people associated with a Minister other than members of that Minister's family. I remind the House and the Prime Minister of a very celebrated case in the United Kingdom in relation to the House of Commons involving a former Chancellor of the Exchequer, Reginald Maudling, who was forced to resign from the Government because of his association with and the business interests of not his mother, his sister or his Aunt Agatha but a former business associate by the name of Poulson. That was the principle applied then. The issue involved was not whether there was any relationship; the issue involved was whether in all the circumstances there was a potential conflict of interest. Everybody knows that if a man who stands to gain as going a beneficiary under an estate to the tune perhaps of a quarter of a million dollars goes out of this Parliament and tries to tell the average Australian that he may not have a conflict of interest in that kind of situation, there is not a man or woman who would believe him. I say to the Minister for Trade that there is not a man or woman on this side of the House who believes him. I dare say that there are many men and women on his side of the House who do not believe him either. There are many people sitting at the back of the Government's own benches who do not believe him. They believe one thing about him-that he has become a colossalliability to his Prime Minister. The Prime Minister has no alternative. He has to come into the Parliament to defend the Minister for Trade. He does not have the strength of character to get rid of the Minister, any more than he had the strength of character or the numbers to get rid of the Special Minister of State when he should have after the report of the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies. He does not have the strength of character to get rid of the Minister now, when he should have got rid of him a couple of years ago. If this happens again in relation to another Minister, as surely it will, he will not have the strength of character to get rid of that Minister either. When it comes to making a choice between his duties as a Prime Minister and cronyism and factional survival, we can bet our bottom dollar that this Prime Minister will always choose cronyism and factional survival. He will never do his dUlY as Prime Minister. He will never apply to his Ministers the standards of propriety and conduct that were applied to Ministers in the former Government. If ever there were a demonstration of conduct that would stand as a memorial to the high standards of conduct of the Ministers in the former coalition Government, it is a comparison of their conduct with the pathetic failure of this Prime Minister to put his duty ahead of his cronyism, and factional survival. By failing to get rid of the Minister for Trade for a demonstrable failure to make a disclosure of matters that may have given rise to a conflict of interests, this Prime Minister has added yet again to his long list of broken promises. An example of the Prime Minister's lack of credibility is the number of promises that he has' broken. His failure to match the expectations and the commitments that he made to the Australian public has become very apparent. Let us remember his glowing statement of September 1983 when he stated: It is right and proper that they should do so. The public, the electors of this country, are entitled to have confidence in the integrity of their elected representatives; to know that Ministers of the Government will perform their duties without fear or favour; to be reassured that a Minister's private interests, whatever they may be, do not conflict with his or her public duties in holding the high office of a Minister in the Federal Government. Mr Rocher-Who said that?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: They were the words of the Prime Minister. Those words were worth as much as that famous promise that he made in 1983 when he said: 'There will be no capital gains tax'. The words were worth as much as that promise that he made in Adelaide in November 1984; 'We have sown the seeds and we are going to reap the harvest of lower interest rates in 1985'. Those words were also worth as much as that promise that he made in the South Australian election campaign: 'We will not lift the interest rate ceiling: You can bet on that. We will not lift the interest rate ceiling'. They were worth as much as the promise that he made: 'There will be no assets test'. They were worth as much as the promise that he made that· he would not increase taxation on lump sum superannuation payments. They were worth as much as the promise that he made that this year inflation would be down to 5 per cent. So the list goes on. The Prime Minister, by his actions over the Dawkins affair, has not only broken yet another of his solemn promises made to the Australian public, but he has also condoned the remaining in office of a Minister who has clearly failed to match the high standards of disclosure that should properly be required of Ministers of the Crown. Yesterday it was plain for everybody in this House to see the embarrassment of the Prime Minister when he tried, in his super clever fashion, to pretend that what the Opposition 'was asserting was ridiculous when contrasted with the practices and the standards of the Fraser Government. Of course, to his great embarrassment, the Prime Minister was caught out. That demonstrated more graphically than anything else the vast gulf that separates both sides of this House so far as ministerial propriety is concerned. Ministerial propriety is not something that can be codified neatly. It is not something that is susceptible to a legalistic interpretation. Ministerial propriety rests on an instinct for honour and proper conduct. If that instinct is absent and if the person occupying the ministerial office has no instinct for honour and proper conduct, the Government cannot expect a performance of the high standards of a Minister from that person. It is perfectly plain that the Minister went along to a meeting of seven Cabinet Ministers to make a decision on the most sensitive and highly publicised commercial issue in Australia over the past 40 years, knowing that his mother holds $250,000 worth of shares in one of the companies under scrutiny and even has the concern and presence of mind to ask everybody present 'Have you got any interests to declare?', in other words, self-righteously and pompously he put everybody else on the rack. Having done that, he then made a deliberate decision. It was not an oversight, because what the Prime Minister did today was to take the debate a little further. When he was asked about the Minister, he said that the Minister addressed the matter and that he made a judgment that it was not necessary to make the disclosure. I have to say to the House that I do not believe that; I do not think that is right. I am not the least bit persuaded by what the Prime Minister said but, if in fact that is the situation, the Minister is incompetent, because his judgment is bad and if, knowing that his mother has shares in the company and knowing the sensitivity of the matter it was not in his mind, he is also incompetent and, on either count, he ought to go. By the Prime Minister defending him and saying that he shares the judgment, the Prime Minister has implicated himself in the bad judgment of his ministerial colleague. To use the words of a number of correspondents in this morning's Press, the Prime Minister has made' an absolute mockery of the rules of ministerial conduct. As far as this Government is concerned, there is no longer such a thing as a code of ministerial conduct and behaviour relating to pecuniary interests. From this day forward anything that this Prime Minister or any of his Ministers have to say about declarations of interests by Ministers or anybody else in the House is so much nonsense and ought to be totally discounted by everybody in the Australian community. This Prime Minister has demonstrated that it is quite okay to have a great long list of requireone's ments, to get people to fill out forms, to move fancy resolutions and to make fine sounding speeches about ministerial propriety and the declaration of pecuniary interests but, when it comes to the crunch and one of his own mob is caught in the web, then we have to forget about the whole lot of it. We have to run around those rules, reinterpret them and pretend that they do not exist. We have to contradict today what we said yesterday, because that Is what the Prime Minister did and anybody who heard the tortuous answers that the Prime Minister gave yesterday wou)d know that he was quite dishonestly and selectively relying upon a very narrow interpretation of the rules. I therefore return to what I said at the commencement of my speech. This matter deals with one very simple proposition which is whether or not, in the circumstances involving the Minister for Trade, there was a potential conflict of interests. It has nothing to do with whether it involved this or that member of the Minister's family. That is not the issue. It could have involved a business associate of the Minister or it could have involved a close personal friend of the Minister. There can be circumstances where the relationship between a Minister and an individual dealing with the Government is sensitive and important. Why does not the Prime Minister ask the Minister of State about that? His relationship with somebody dealing with the Government turned out, on a very celebrated occasion, to be very sensitive and very important; so it has. nothing at all to do with whether or not a relationship exists but, rather, whether, in all of the circumstances, the facts suggest that a potential conflict of interests arose. On this occasion, that was clearly the case. If, on this occasion, the facts do not bring forth that conclusion it seems inconceivable to me and to others on this side of the House that any facts can bring forth that conclusion. The Prime Minister, by his actions and weakness, his inability to discipline and expel from the Ministry the Minister for Trade and by breaking a promise has further confirmed in the minds of the Australian public that, when it really comes to the crunch, when he really has a gut issue upon which to make a decision, when he has to choose between duty which might be lonely, hard, unpopular and give him a few sleepless nights but it is still the right thing to do, and cronyism, he will take the latter course. When one has to make that choice, but one has an alternative, and that is to smooth it all over, to pretend it has not happened, to stand by cronies, to serve the interests of factional survival, one can be absolutely certain that yours truly, the present Prime Minister, will always choose the latter course of action. This has occurred not only on this occasion in relation to the Minister for Trade, it applied to the Special Minister of State. If ever anybody deserved to get flung out of the Ministry, it was the Special Minister of State. One cannot do much worse than go into a car park and blab one's mouth about something that might affect the national security of this country. Yet here he is, as large as life, sitting on the front bench, continuing to enjoy the fruits of office, continuing to enjoy being a member of the Hawke Government. That is an example of the Government's standards. They apply not only to Ministers-the Special Minister of State and the Minister for Trade. Of course, we all remember that when the crunch really came on a political issue such as the MX missile, and on issues that were of enormous importance to this country, the Prime Minister once again was willing to choose expediency instead of his duty to do the right thing and the strong thing. I conclude my reading from the remarks of Sir John Simon on the principles applying to Ministers: Inasmuch as the secrets of the Government are specially in charge of Cabinet ministers, no minister and particularly, no Cabinet minister, must in any circumstances put himself in a position where he is not able to be the complete guardian of those secrets in that there is any possibility of any private interests being served through a knowledge of those secrets. I put it to the House that that definition applies immaculately to the circumstances of this case. The Minister for Trade should go and the Prime Minister should be censured for not making him go.

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Members of the Opposition set their. standards, they say, and there is a vast Let us look at their standards. Let us take the most obvious example that occurred in 1982. They established a royal commission in 1981 to look at what had happened in the meat industry. They did not have a Cabinet committee of inquiry; they established a royal commission. Mr Justice Woodward, their appointed royal commissioner, brought down his report, which included one of the most damning indictments of a Minister-the then Minister for Primary Industry-in the history of this country. What did that Government that members of the Opposition talk about, the one with these great standards, do? They talk about the absence of cronyism. I will tell honourable members opposite what it did. The then Prime Minister went into a cabal with the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party and with the leaders of the National Party of Australia. They said: 'Here we have this royal commission report, damning a Minister in a way in which a Minister has never been damned before by a royal commission. What shall we do?' The Minister thought that he had better resign. But we could not have that, could we? What did the then Prime Minister, this man of standards, this man of probity, do? What did this Government with an instinct for honour do? It set about attacking the royal commissioner: It did not accept his report, which demanded, on any standards of decency, the resignation of the Minister. What did it do? Did it accept the resignation of the Minister? No, it did not. It attacked and damned the royal commissioner. That is the standard of honour and the instinct for decency of members of the Opposition. Let us hear no more of this vast gulf. In government honourable members opposite were not only grossly incompetent but also totally dishonourable. There has never been another instance in the history of this country when a government has appointed a royal commission, that royal commission has brought down a finding which cried out for the resignation of a Minister, and the then Prime Minister has said: 'No, we will not do that. We will attack the royal commissioner'. The speech that has just been delivered must rank as the most hypocritical ever delivered in this· Parliament. Having established the hypocrisy of the Leader of the Opposition, let us restore some rationality to this debate. Let me rehearse the rules about conflicts of interest that apply to Ministers and the history of those rules. Before this Government was elected the history of conflicts of ingulf. terest was one of the previous Government being dragged, screaming and kicking, by the then Labor Opposition towards the registration of Ministers' and members' interests. It was as a result, Madam Speaker, as you will recall, of the sustained pressure from the then Labor Opposition that the previous Government commissioned the Bowen Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest. When the report was finally received it took the then Government nearly six months just to table it. At that belated stage it moved to ask Cabinet Ministers to declare their private interests to the Prime Minister and to establish some rules in the declaration of interests. Those rules were stated broadly, but not, I might add, as some gullible observers have been led into believing because of some high sense of probity but rather because that Government was too frightened to define them with any precision. Its sense of probity and its rules were so well defined that the then Minister for Primary Industry, I remind members of the House, and the public, was able, under its rules-its rules, characterised by an instinct for honour and of great probity-to authorise a payment of $800,000 to the Murray Goulburn Co-operative Co. Ltd in which he was a direct and substantial shareholder. Like so much of the Fraser Government, it was a matter of form without any content, of rhetoric without any substance. When this Government came to power we moved to give meaning and content to those nebl!lous rules. We defined the rules for Cabinet Ministers. We required full details to be lodged with the Prime Minister and we published Ministers' interests in this House. We have in addition spent the last two years dragging this Opposition, still kicking and screaming, towards a registration of members' interests. Members of the public may care to review the debates on the motion on members' interests to appreciate the contribution and attitude of the Opposition on this matter. One member of the Opposition, the honourable member for O'Connor ( Mr Tuckey), said quite openly that he hoped it would provide him with more dirt for him to throw at members of the Government. That is a measure of the Opposition in this matter. Where the Government has sought to establish probity, the Opposition rakes for muck. If one asks specifically for the position of members of the Opposition, it turns out that they are opposed even to declaring their spouses' interests to this House. That is their high minded position in this matter. They want members on this side of the House to declare interests that they do not even know about, while they declare nothing and hide behind their own self-interest. It will be interesting to see whether they have sufficient respect for the institution of parliament to submit to its resolution in this regard, or whether as usual they will be driven by self-interest and fear. The relative positions of the Government and the Opposition have been and remain perfectly distinct. The Government's position has been one of giving substance and codification to the requirements of public duty. The position of the Opposition has been to avoid and evade at all times on this issue. The rules covering Ministers are clearly set out in paragraph 215 of the Cabinet handbook-published, I might add, for the first time under this Government. Those requirements are explicit in requiring Ministers to declare the private interests of themselves and members of their immediate families. The phase 'immediate families' is explicitly defined in the guidelines issued to Ministers when completing their public interest returns. Madam Speaker, I table the guidelines for the information of the House. It is interesting to reflect on what might have happened to the previous Minister for. Primary Industry under those rules. The rules are explicit, they are clear. They were made clear in my statement to this House on 22 September, and they were not opposed by the Opposition. They are a significant advance on the loopholeridden vagaries of the previous Government. It is a matter of record and of pride to this Government that these standards represent the highest form of standards adopted by any government for the conduct of its Ministers. As can be seen, these rules were properly applied in the Bell-BHP considerations. When the ministerial committee was formed to deal with the Bell Resources bid for BHP the conflict of interest arrangements which I have set out applied to the committee. In fact, as is known, when the committee first met it was the Minister for Trade who raised the issue of a conflict of interest. In response to his question I asked each Minister in turn whether any conflict of interest existed, and each replied in the negative. The Minister for Trade made the judgment at that point that any holding of his mother's, the details of which he was unaware, did not constitute a conflict of interest for him. That judgment was sound both within the formal conflict of interest rules and, putting the rules aside, it was taken, as I shall demonstrate, as logic and common sense would dictate. The Opposition has tried to suggest that by raising the issue himself the Minister for Trade was not expressing his natural concern for the proprieties of government but was indulging in clever deceit. It is a useful rule of life, Madam Speaker, and Occam's law should be remembered: To reject a fanciful explanation when a simple one is at hand. This event shows simply that the Minister for Trade was alive to the issue and had tested it in his mind. It indicates that he was sensitive to the Cabinet as a whole being able to operate unimpeded by personal interest. It indicates that he had considered the issue and found no personal interest of his own which would conflict with his public duty. Indeed, the individual questioning of Ministers in Cabinet that day was a fuller process than was technically required by the rules of this Government-let alone, of course by the rules of the previous Government. No doubt, in the face of these facts, the Opposition would assert that the Minister's judgment was either deliberately negligent or deficient. The fact that the Minister himself raised the issue immediately despatches the first of those two possibilities as being quite nonsensical. So, let us examine the second possibility. There is no doubt that the correct view in these matters, reflected from the Bowen report, 1979, right through to the resolution of this House in February this year, is that the interests of a Minister's immediate family are shared by a Minister, who cannot divorce himself or herself from them, no matter how principled or wellintentioned a person he or she is. For this the Cabinet rules established by my Government and the parliamentary rules established by this House are explicit ih this regard. Beyond immediate family, no sensible or useful single line can be drawn. Individual members and Ministers enjoy quite different circumstances in their lives, and what might be appropriate to one may be unnecessary or inappropriate to others. All situations could only be encompassed by throwing a net so widely as to make any formal scheme of reporting unworkable. In addition, a wide throwing of the net is an unreasonable intrusion into the privacy of a large number of citizens, who are entitled, unless there are clear public interests to be served to have their privacy. Considerations of interest beyond immediate family must therefore be individual to each case. We ask ourselves: 'What is the case here?' The Minister was not aware of the size or the details of his mother's holdings. His mother is an independent woman, she has her own means. Conversely, the Minister is not dependent on his mother. By community standards they are both people of means. Their financial affairs are separate. On these facts, the only practical judgment is that their interests are separate. There is no link beyond that of maternity which would require the public interest to dictate that the Minister inform himself of the details of his mother's wealth or disqualify himself where those details may conflict with his public duty. The only judgment that common sense and logic allow in balancing these issues is the judgment that the Minister made-namely, that there was no conflict of interest-and it is a judgment that I endorse. The Government's position in this matter is clear. It has a history and a clear record of demanding high standards of behaviour from Ministers. It has codified and strengthened the hitherto vague and loophole-ridden efforts of the Opposition, and it has not shirked the difficult positions in this area. In this issue, Madam Speaker, the Government has observed the proprieties of Cabinet beyond what was required by the rules. The Minister's judgment has been vindicated by the facts. By contrast, history indicates that Opposition members, when. in a scandal-ridden Fraser Government and latterly in opposition, have resisted at every turn any disclosure of interest by Ministers or members. The contrast is stark. They repudiated a royal commIssIOn which demanded the resignation of one of their Ministers and they attacked the reason royal commissioner. Members opposite are hypocrites and they will be so judged by the people of this country.

The Menzies, MCMahon and Gorton governments had very clear guidelines. - illy MCMahon went before the Riordan Committee into Pecuniary Interests of Members of Parliament and said that it Was left to the Minister to declde what he should disclose to the Prime Minister. He said that sometimes the Prime Minister was interested and· sometimes he was not. That was Billy MCMahon, the ex-Prime Minister, giving evidence to the Riordan Committee about the disclosure of public interests. That has· always been the case. The House of Commons has had difficulty with the rules it has applied and there is no sanction if members there do not comply. Even after the deliberations of the Riordan Committee, the Bowen Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest and whatever else we try, this Parliament will not get it exactly right, but it will evolve eventually that the people of Australia can expect that parliamentarians in the national Parliament will disclose their public interests so that when debates take place on matters of national interest we are able to see in very general terms what a member's private interest is. That has been the policy of the Labor Party for decades.

Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: I will tell the Deputy Leader of the Opposition about it. He is kinky about my private interests. The Prime Minister announced after that that in future Ministers' declarations would be tabled along with the declarations of all other members of parliament. If Opposition members want to know about the sorts of problems they can get into, I refer to a very interesting article I read in the New Idea. I do not normally get New Idea, but since members opposite have been in opposition I have been reading it regularly .. There is an article by the widow of Phil Lynch. Phil Lynch was not a personal friend of mine but he was a very dedicated politician-dedicated to the Liberal Party-as was shown by his performance in this Parliament. When the Liberal Party. got into trouble in 1977, when Phil Lynch was ill, there was a public dispute about whether he had disclosed to the then Prime Minister some private interests he held in Victoria. Phil Lynch, until the day he died, considered that everything he did was proper and correct and that there was no question about what he did. Malcolm Fraser sacked Phil Lynch while he was in hospital. Not only that-honourable members opposite should read the article in the latest New Idea-but people from the Liberal Party would not even talk to him. Honourable members opposite should read the article to see the sorts of problems which can be presented to a political party on these issues. The former Government sacked Phil Lynch, not because of anything that it thought was right or wrong but because it swung with the motion of the 1977 election. Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: The right honourable member is on record, going back 20 years, as being totally opposed to the disclosure of member's interests. The House of Commons, the United States Congress and four State parliaments in Australia do it, but he does not want the Commonwealth Parliament to do it. We will do it, by resolution of this House. There will be a register of members' interests. We have taken the advice of the Standing Committee on Members' Interests in terms of the way in which the form ought to be designed. There is a split of opinion about how far we should go in this Parliament. One can read in the Press on any day of the week, when this issue comes up, it will break about fiftyfifty; 50 per cent say that there should not be disclosure and 50 per cent say that there should. But it is something that the Parliament has to decide. This Parliament has decided that way. I conclude on this point. It is rather ironic that the Prime Minister of the first Government to institute this procedure, for which there has been a crying need for years and years in this Parliament, should be censured for the actions he has taken. A lot of other Prime Ministers should have done it but did not. It is indicative . of this Government-a fact which must be faced up to by the Opposition-that this is the best government Australia has had since World War II. It is the best not only in terms of policy and administration but also in the way in which these matters are presented to the public, and that is why it will be re-elected whenever that chance may come. The opportunity for all honourable members to declare their interests is now out of the way. Title: NOES
text: Gellibrand-Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations) (4.19)-I move: That the amendments be agreed to. In so moving I should explain the background of what is being proposed by the Senate and why the Government is accepting these amendments. The proposed amendment is to clause 5 of the Bill which relates to registration. Clause 5, as passed by this House, had in sub-clause I (a) provision for a period of three years to elapse from the day of commencement of this Act before the Builders Labourers Federation would be able to reapply for registration in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. We believed that provision was important, as I explained to the House previously during the Committee stage of the Bill, because in our view NOES it was necessary for there to be such a period in which the BLF was not able to come before the Commission in any form. We believed it was necessary to have a period in which the industry Spender. J. M. could settle down on a new basis without the BLF being in any way a factor before the Commission and there being no concern about its prospective reregistration. We believed that a three-year period was sufficient for that purpose. The Bill also provides that, following that three year period, if the Federation were to seek to reregister it would have to overcome two imporBILL 1986 tant threshold points which are also included in clause 5. It would have to convince a full bench of the Arbitration Commission that the registration would not be inimical to the system of conciliation and arbitration and would not be damaging in any way to the objects of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. 1986 Those were the two key grounds found by the Commission to be areas where the BLF was massively in breach and therefore this would clearly be a massive problem for the Federation to overcome unless there was a dramatic transformation in the nature of the organisation. However, once the Federation overcame those In Committee obstacles, if it were able to do so, it would then have to face registration in circumstances where the work had been reallocated and presumably there would be very strong opposition from the unions that had received the allocation of that work and probably from other parties as well. In our view, the provisions in the current Bill are sufficient for the purposes of ensuring a situation in the building industry in which there would be no prospect of the Federation being around for a considerable number of years. I point out that, in 1975, when the Federation sought to reregister, it took 18 months to do so despite the fact that there was no opposition from other unions, employers or governments to its application. In a situation where the Federation would have to leap the threshold issues which I have already mentioned and also face strong opposition to its registration from unions and other parties, it .would be highly likely that it would take several years for it to achieve that, if in fact it could achieve it. I believe that it would be very difficult indeed. Essentially, we believe that the provisions in the Bill would be satisfactory and would meet the needs as the Government sees them. However, the Senate has decided to amend that to increase the three-year period of exclusion from the Commission to five years. We are concerned that, if we rejected this, there would be delay and this legislation would possibly be jeopardised. That is something which we could not contemplate and, therefore, in the circumstances facing us-the need to get this legislation through as quickly as possible and not to jeopardise its future-we believe the Government should accept this amendment; and we do so accordingly.

Commonwealth-State Relations: National (Question No. 3180) Mr MCVeigh asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 February 1986 (redirected to the Minister for Finance): (I) Under the Commonwealth/State Government arrangements for national disaster proposals, is there a difference between funds available for restoration of roads and funds for repairs to sewerage and water supply facilities; if so, what are the reasons for the difference. (2) Is it a fact that in some areas sewerage and water supplies are the responsibility of local authorities.

Speaker: Mr HURFORD
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
text: The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (I) Under the Natural Disaster Relief Arrangements (NORA), the Commonwealth provides financial assistance to the States to help meet the cost of relief and restoration relating to eligible natural disasters. The arrangements recognise that the States have the primary responsibility for the provision and administration of relief measures. Expenditure by the States on the restoration of assets of a public undertaking which provides community, social or economic services outside the normal market mechanism, either free of charge or at a nominal charge well below the cost of production, is covered by the NORA. On the other hand expenditure on the restoration of assets owned by a financial or trading undertaking which recovers all or a significant proportion of its operating costs is not eligible under the scheme. Whether a particular service provided by a local authority would be covered by the NORA would depend on the circumstances of the case. Under the arrangements, that would be a - matter primarily for consideration by the States in the first instance. Since charges are not generally imposed on road users, State expenditure on the restoration of roads damaged by an eligible natural disaster would usually be covered by-the NORA. On the other hand, some or all of the cost of the provision of sewerage and water supply services would often be recovered by charges on users, either directly or indirectly through general rates. In these cases, State expenditure on the restoration of such facilities would not generally be eligible for Commonwealth assistance under the NORA. H is considered appropriate that financial and trading undertakings, like private businesses, should meet the cost of damage caused by natural disasters through commercial insurance, or internally funded self-insurance. Such insurance costs are a normal business expense and, like other costs, should be reflected in charges. (2) Yes. Pests and Diseases (Question No. 3199) Mr MCVeigh asked the Minister for Primary Industry, on notice, on 14 February 1986: (I) Have the programs for eradication of cattle disDisaster eases initiated by the Fraser/Anthony coalition Government been successful; if so, is the $4 per head levy paid by beef producers still required to fund eradication programs. (2) Will he reduce the levy to $1.50 per head as requested by industry leaders. Mr Kerin-The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows: (I) The national bovine brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign was not initiated by the 'Fraser Anthony coalition Government'. It commenced in 1970 as a co-operative Commonwealth/State/Industry program, and has been successful in its progress to date. [n respect of brucellosis, Australia was declared provisionally free (that is, a prevalence of less than 2 infected breeding cattle per 1,000 head) in January 1986. Western Australia and Tasmania are free of the disease. Australia's success at controlling bovine brucellosis compares very favourably with equivalent programs in overseas countries. At 30 June 1985, there were only 193 (0.13%) infected herds containing 202,550 breeder cattle (1.6%). This is expected to be reduced to 48 herds by 30 June 1986, 8 herds by 30 June 1987 and nil infected herds by 3(; June 1989. It is confidently anticipated that Australia will be declared free of bovine brucellosis by 1992 or earlier. [n respect of tuberculosis, Tasmania is free of the disease and New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and the ACT are provisionally free (ie. a prevalence of less than one infected animal per 1,000 head). Major difficulties have been encountered in extensive pastoral areas in Australia's north due to lack of facilities for controlling cattle. Nevertheless progress to date has been steady. There wer.- 347 (0.2%) infected herds at 30 June 1985 carrying 1.75m head (7.8%). It is expected that the number of infected herds will be reduced to 283 by June 1986 and to 235 by June 1987. The Commonwealth is acutely aware of the need to plan with care the progress of the campaign from now till its completion in 1992. Recrudescences of brucellosis are a very real possibility and every effort is being made to maintain the present level of monitoring activity. Based on projections of income and expenditure of the National Cattle Disease Eradication Trust Account in the years up to 1992, the $4 per head levy is being examined. The factors which impinge upon these projections are complex and the Government is considering these factors in association with the estimated projections. (2) No request has been received to reduce the levy to $1.50. However the Cattle Council of Australia and other organisations have requested that it be reduced to $2.50. This request is being considered in the light of the information available on the future conduct of the campaign. (2) Will local authorities affected by bush fires in N.S.W. and Victoria experience changes to their natural disaster relief arrangements under the new amendments.

Speaker: Mr HURFORD
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
text: The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (I) Under the Natural Disaster Relief Arrangements (NORA), the Commonwealth provides financial assistance to the States to help meet the cost of relief and restoration relating to eligible natural disasters. The arrangements recognise that the States have the primary responsibility for the provision and administration of relief measures. Following a comprehensive review of the scheme, a number of changes to the arrangements were phased in during 1984-85 and 1985-86. The major changes were: (a) increases in, and indexation of, annual base amounts of State expenditure (above which a State is entitled to Commonwealth assistance) so as to restore cost-sharing between the States and Commonwealth to a more equitable level; (b) transfer to the States of responsibility for selecting, within agreed guidelines, the specific measures to be eligible for assistance; (c) exclusion from the scheme of financial and trading undertakings of State and local governments other than railways (non-trading undertakings continue to be eligible); (d) inclusion of formerly ineligible minor disasters within the scheme. The effect of these changes to the arrangements on local authorities, including those affected by Cyclone Winifred, would depend on the way in which the scheme is administered by each State and on the nature of the services provided by the authorities. Services provided by local authorities outside the normal market mechanism, either free of charge or at a nominal charge well below the cost of production, would continue to be covered by the NORA. (Question No. 3375) Mr Lloyd asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 13 March 1986: (I) Is it a fact that there is a threat of citrus canker entering Australia via citrus imports, particularly from the United States of America; if so, what quarantine measures are being taken to prevent the entry of the disease. (2) Is research being undertaken to assess the potential threat to the citrus industry if the disease enters and spreads within Australia. Mr Kerin-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) There is no threat of citrus canker entering Australia via citrus imports particularly from the United States of America. The importation of citrus is not permitted from areas in which citrus canker exists. This in effect precludes imports from Asia, Pacific Island countries, Africa, Central America and South America. Citrus imports which are not considered to pose a quarantine risk are currently permitted from California (USA), Israel and New Zealand. Although canker was detected in Florida, USA, there is no threat of canker spreading to other States because of the strong measures taken for its eradication. (2) No research is being undertaken to assess the potential threat to the citrus industry if canker enters and spreads within Australia. However, information is being constantly gathered from overseas research and the progress of the current eradication campaign in Florida is being carefully watched. Action plans have been drawn up for eradication of exotic plant pests and diseases should they appear in Australia and the plan for canker was put into effect when the disease was recently detected on Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Thursday Island in the Torres Strait. Eradication on these islands is considered feasible because of their isolation and the limited number of trees involved.
